articles.title: Burgaw Mayor to speak with Western North Carolina officials about flooding
articles.author: Conor Doherty
articles.summary: Burgaw Mayor Olivia Dawson is in western North Carolina to speak to other leaders about flood-ravaged towns and communities. Dawson is part of the National Member Advisory Board for the American Flood Coalition. She'll be talking about recovery in Burgaw in the aftermath of Hurricanes Matthew and Florence.

articles.title: ‘People aren't forgetting': Burgaw mayor collaborates with Western NC leaders on rebuilding efforts
articles.author: Ava Brendgord
articles.summary: It's been four months since Hurricane Helene hit Western North Carolina. Burgaw Mayor Olivia Dawson has traveled to Asheville to share her experiences and lessons learned with leaders there. Helene caused roughly $60 billion in damages to North Carolina, which is over three times as much damage as Hurricane Florence did nearly 7 years ago.

articles.title: Eyewitness News at 5pm - January 30, 2025
articles.summary: NC Hurricane survivors may not get homes rebuilt without more funding for hurricane relief.      Â   for more funding  for Hurricane relief. For more information, go to: http://www.cnn.com/news/helping-hurricane-victims-rebuild-homes.

articles.title: Kenya's Long Rains to Start Early with Mixed Regional Patterns
articles.author: Martin Olage
articles.summary: Kenya Meteorological Department has revealed that the anticipated long rains for March-April-May are projected to start earlier than usual this year, beginning in February. Some regions may see increased rainfall, while others could see the precipitation tapering off by mid to late May. The weather changes will affect various sectors differently.

articles.title: Record-breaking January heat brings warmth to La Crosse residents
articles.author: Gavin Michaelson
articles.summary: La Crosse reached 58 degrees Thursday afternoon, breaking the previous record for the month at 57 degrees. The lack of snow and warm air caused the abnormally warm weather. The January will be close to the average temperature. Officials advise people to be cautious on ice over waterways.

articles.title: Free University of Calgary e-course tackles climate change misinformation
articles.author: Paula Tran
articles.summary: A new free e-course at the University of Calgary aims to tackle misinformation and disinformation about climate change. Preparing Albertans for Climate Change presents evidence-based information on climate change impacts and solutions in a local Alberta context across six modules. All six modules provide examples of local projects and initiatives in Alberta and actions individuals can incorporate into their everyday lives.

articles.title: How Prepared Are You For Natural Disasters In Seal Beach?
articles.author: Rachel Barnes
articles.summary: The City of Seal Beach is planning to update its local hazard mitigation plan and is looking for community input to gauge how knowledgeable residents are about natural disasters. The city prepared a survey to help officials understand what concerns are important to Seal Beach residents and how to reduce risks.

articles.title: News 11 Weather: Continued warming
articles.author: Scott Gross
articles.summary: As we get closer to the weekend, expect a continued warming trend to push local temperatures anywhere from 10 to 15 degrees above normal. Dry conditions will prevail through the next week or so. The average temperatures for this time of year is around 70 degrees. However, highs across lower desert areas could reach the lower and middle 80s.

articles.title: The Mindful Minute by Jon Heydenreich: I Do Not Get it
articles.author: Jon Heydenreich
articles.summary: Some people are moving to Phoenix, Ariz. because of climate change. In Phoenix it is above 110 degrees for 30 days for over 130 days straight. It cools down at night to the mid 90s. There is no grass in Phoenix. People do not go outside for months.

articles.title: 2024 Breaks Heat Records in the Dutch Caribbean, Reports KNMI
articles.author: Vordev
articles.summary: The year 2024 was officially the hottest year ever recorded in the Dutch Caribbean, with an average temperature of 28.4°C on Sint Maarten, Sint Eustatius, Saba, Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao. The dry season at the beginning of the year was drier than average across all Dutch Caribbean islands, but the wet season was weter than normal. New all-in-one weather stations were installed on Bonair in 2024.

articles.title: The Withering Land
articles.author: Ume Habiba Naseem
articles.summary: Pakistan contributes less than one per cent to global greenhouse gas emissions, but it is one of the most affected countries by climate change. The nation is witnessing an environmental decline, driven by the rising intensity of heatwaves and deforestation. Heatwaves have become a recurring nightmare for Pakistan, with temperatures soaring to unprecedented levels. Deforestation is silently exacerbating the crisis, with only about 5 percent of Pakistan's land area under forests.

articles.title: Rising global temperatures linked to bird population decline in remote areas
articles.author: Bob Yirka
articles.summary: A team of environmental scientists from the Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia, Michigan Technologic University and the University of Oregon has found a link between rising global temperatures and the decline in bird populations in remote areas around the world. Previous research has shown that bird populations have been reduced virtually everywhere, even in places untouched by human encroachment.

articles.title: To the Lifehouse
articles.author: Hannah Proctor
articles.summary: A new book rediscovers lessons from Black Panther survival programmes, solidarity networks of crisis-era Greece and the Occupy Sandy disaster relief efforts. The book asks whether impending climate catastrophe means we should stop waiting and start doing. Hurricane Helene, the deadliest to hit mainland USA since Hurricane Katrina in 2005, struck the Big Bend region of Florida in late September 2024. The damage inflicted by natural disasters in the US is sometimes reported in terms of insured losses.

articles.title: The Planet Came With Instructions: How We Ignored Indigenous Wisdom And Chose Chaos Instead​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​.
articles.author: Kelly Oxford
articles.summary: Colonizers ignored 10,000 years of indigenous knowledge with 200 years of industrial "progress" and we're watching our planet die in real time because of this mistake.   .   i.e. thinking we could outsmart people who lived here for thousands of years without setting the atmosphere on fire.

articles.title: Can We Still Solve Climate Change?
articles.summary: The Earth's average temperature has exceeded 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels for the first time. Extreme weather is getting more frequent and severe. The world has been doing a lot to reduce emissions. President Trump's decision to leave the Paris Agreement is bad for the world, but there are some silver linings.

articles.title: Simplifying Fund Allocation Processes Key To Enhance Disaster Response Efficiency: IIT-B Study
articles.author: Vikrant Jha
articles.summary: IIT-B study highlights inefficiencies in the existing disaster relief mechanisms, especially in the allocation of funds through the National and State Disaster Response Funds (NDRF and SDRF). Natural disasters such as floods and cyclones cause significant financial strain on the government. Coastal states such as Odisha, Andhra Pradesh, and West Bengal face greater economic challenges due to high recovery expenses and external funding.

articles.title: I've lived in Australia, Canada and the UK. Here's my ranking of each
articles.author: Kirsten Powley
articles.summary: Born and raised in London, she was determined to live Down Under by whatever means necessary. She studied in Melbourne and later in Toronto, where she met her now-husband. After a two-year long-distance relationship, they now live together in London. Australia's weather is stunning. Canada's weather fluctuates wildly.

articles.title: How to tell if that tree-change dream house is actually a nightmare
articles.author: Jim Malo
articles.summary: As the climate changes, Australia will become more exposed to natural disasters such as fires, floods, cyclones, storms, extreme heat and coastal inundation. The warning comes after the Los Angeles fires, which have taken at least 25 lives and devastated thousands of homes. Climate change is thought to have contributed to the disaster by increasing the region's fuel load.

articles.title: The coming update to The New Hampshire Coastal Flood Risk Summary
articles.author: Michael Quinn
articles.summary: The New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services has announced the required update to the 2019-2020 New Hampshire Coastal Flood Risk Summary. The report will be of use in three specific types of projects: planning projects, hazard mitigation plans, post disaster redevelopment and site specific projects.

articles.title: North Carolina officials make urgent request to lawmakers on Helene and other hurricanes
articles.summary: Western North Carolina will need billions more dollars from the federal and state government to accomplish its recovery goals. The region saw historic flooding from Hurricane Helene last year, which resulted in almost $60 billion in damages. Eastern North Carolina is still struggling from previous hurricanes.

articles.title: Most of Britain's peat bogs could stop forming new peat as the climate changes
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: By the 2080s, most of Britain's peatlands will be too dry to form new peat. That's according to a new academic study by Joe Dunckley and his colleagues, published in the Journal of Applied Applied.

articles.title: Climate Change Increased Likelihood Of L.A. Wildfires, Report Finds
articles.summary: The recent Southern California wildfires killed at least 29 people and destroyed more than 16,000 buildings. The study analyzed weather and climate models to assess how a warmer atmosphere is increasing the likelihood of fire-prone weather. The extreme conditions driving the recent fires in Los Angeles are now expected to occur once every 17 years, compared to once every 23 years without climate change.

articles.title: Lightning becomes a threat
articles.author: Zaheer Udin Babar Junejo
articles.summary: Tharparkar, a region in Sindh, has seen a dramatic increase in lightning-related incidents since 2011. 98 lives were lost, 33 people were injured and 1,756 animals perished due to lightning strikes in the last five years. Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) Sindh and Fast Rural Development Program (FRDP) have launched a project to investigate the causes, impacts, and precautions related to lightning. The project includes the installation of communal lightning protection rods in hotspot areas to mitigate risks.

articles.title: Humans are causing modern warming; other things caused past climate change
articles.author: Kate S. Petersen
articles.summary: A Facebook post claims that Earth's climate has been changing for 4.5 billion years and humans are to blame for modern climate change. There is no scientific evidence to support this claim. The fact that Earth has been warmer and colder in the past doesn't mean that the current warming trend is dangerous.

articles.title: Central Florida is thawing out, no longer in the top 10 for the coldest January on record
articles.author: Michelle Morgan
articles.summary: January started off cold, with temperatures well below normal for much of the month. Since Jan. 26, average highs have been in the 70s. Orlando now ranks 12th coldest for January on record. If the warm trend continues, that ranking is likely to rise even further. Daytona Beach has moved up to 7th place with an average temperature of 52.8 degrees.

articles.title: ‘Everyone has an impact': how to start reducing your environmental footprint
articles.author: Madeleine Aggeler
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record. Average global temperatures rose to 1.6C above preindustrial levels. Food production has a huge impact on the environment. People should focus on reducing their consumption, reusing and recycling, and investing in environmentally sustainable funds.

articles.title: ‘They have to do what they said': Frustration as Whirinaki flood resilience costs rise
articles.author: Linda Hall
articles.summary: Whirinaki resident Lyn Noanoa wants the regional council to be accountable and do what it said it would. The council has applied to the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment for additional funding to complete the flood-resistance work. The project was initially planned to provide a one-in-100-year level of service for Pōhutukawa Drive residents, and assumed minimal upgrades would be needed for the community's biggest employer Pan Pac.

articles.title: 9 major cities could be underwater by 2100 - here's how they would look
articles.author: Hiyah Zaidi
articles.summary: Global sea levels will rise by 1.9 metres by 2100 if carbon dioxide emissions continue to spike. Bangkok is sinking at 4cm per year, while the Gulf of Thailand is rising at 0.25 cm per year. New Orleans is sinking by 6.4mm per year and Ho Chi Minh City is sinking up to 2-5cm a year. Amsterdam's lowest level is 22ft below sea level. Hamburg's port has been elevated twice after flooding episodes.

articles.title: Housing fund projects revealed as affordability rankles
articles.author: Andrew Brown
articles.summary: "The 'Australian Dream' of home ownership is turning into something closer to a nightmare," says the report. It is based on the ideal of homeownership as a marker of progress, success and stability.      .   i

articles.title: Warmth is weakening the polar vortex. Here's what it means for extreme cold
articles.author: Scott Dance
articles.summary: There is no evidence that extreme cold is becoming more frequent or intense, but rising temperatures in the Arctic are weakening weather systems that normally trap the cold around the poles. This shift is encouraging the erratic weather patterns high in the atmosphere that can cast chills even on regions with typically balmy climates.

articles.title: Fast ice thickness trends focus of study
articles.author: John Lewis
articles.summary: Analysis of more than 30 years of data on the thickness of landfast sea-ice in Antarctica's McMurdo Sound has revealed climate change does not yet appear to be having an effect on its thickness. Storm events, air temperature and winter wind speed are the key influences determining thickness of fast ice. Fast ice is frozen ocean water that is attached to shorelines and persists for at least 15 days.

articles.title: Troxler gives mix of good, bad news about NC agriculture
articles.summary: N.C. Agriculture Commissioner Steve Troxler believes there must be an infusion of capital if agriculture in the state is going to get through the impact of Hurricane Helene in September and a 2024 of low commodity prices and high production costs. He made the remarks Wednesday at the second annual Agriculture Forum held in the Rocky Mount Event Center.

articles.title: The History of The Climate Change Movement in Canada
articles.author: Brett Hawes
articles.summary: The origins of the climate change movement can be traced back to the 1960's and the Club of Rome. Dan Fourier and Dane Wigington of Geoengineering Watch discuss the Club's influence on global policy and their shift from 'global warming' to 'climate change' on Today's Show.

articles.title: Trump's second administration could rewrite his previous one on climate change
articles.author: Rakesh Agrawal
articles.summary: The U.S. President pulled out of the Paris Agreement on climate change in January 2016. Global temperature has risen by 1.07°C since 1950. Sea level rise has increased by 3.4 millimeters per year since 1992. The Caribbean Islands are already experiencing the effects of climate change.

articles.title: Britannia: Preparing the maritime industry for severe weather
articles.author: SAFETY4SEA
articles.summary: Britannia P&I Club has examined impacts and forms of severe weather at sea, especially due to climate change, highlighting best practices for the maritime industry to mitigate the risks. According to Britannia, it is essential to take steps to reduce the impact of climate change at sea.

articles.title: Letter to the Editor: How Many More Cities Must Burn?
articles.summary: According to the UN's Sixth Assessment Report, at 1.5C of global heating, Southern California is projected to experience hotter days, drier soil, and heavier rain. We are currently at about 1.4C. Over the last two years, we experienced significantly higher rainfall, followed by a prolonged dry spell lasting seven months. This led to a build up of vegetation, dried out Eaton Canyon and turned it into a well-supplied tinderbox. According to World Weather Attribution, the Eaton Fire was 35% more probable due to the warming effects that burning fossil fuels has had on our climate. Two years ago, Pasadena City Council declared a climate emergency and set a goal

articles.title: Climate activist on 50-city UK clean-up tour calls for action above disruption
articles.author: Lynn Rusk
articles.summary: 'It's not just about climate change overall, but it's more about the small things that are responsible for climate change. Individual action, people's attitudes – we need to do something about that,' says Mr. Cameron.       "We need to take action on small things."

articles.title: Disaster Recovery Center in Greenwood County reopens
articles.author: RENEE ORTIZ
articles.summary: The Disaster Recovery Center in Greenwood County has reopened until Jan. 31 to provide in-person assistance to South Carolinians affected by Hurricane Helene. The center is located at United Way of the Lakelands, 929 Phoenix St. in Greenwood, South Carolina.

articles.title: Trying to make sense of wild winds and a weird winter
articles.author: Jeff Lowenfels
articles.summary: It was almost 40 degrees last weekend in Alaska, but it was almost minus 5 degrees in the north. The weather is very unusual for this time of the year. The growing season in Alaska is twice as long as it was 100 years ago, and it has added 15 to 20 days since Jeff started writing these columns almost 50 years ago.

articles.title: Mapped: Donald Trump's Transatlantic Anti-Green Network
articles.author: Who What Why
articles.summary: Donald Trump's second term as president of the United States comes at an ever-more critical time for climate change. Climate scientists have warned that 2024 was the hottest year on record and without dramatic action to cut greenhouse gas, it will be even worse in the future.

articles.title: ‘Not normal at all': Rising temperatures threaten saguaros, other native plants in Arizona
articles.author: Makayla O'Bannon
articles.summary: July 2024 will be Earth's hottest month on record. Arizonans faced the grim reality of record-breaking temperatures and extreme arid conditions. Residents had to seek refuge inside from the relentless heat in the summer of 2024, because of the extreme weather conditions.

articles.title: Weather change linked to increased risk of Salmonella outbreaks
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Climate change is impacting the spread of Salmonella, according to new research. Previous research found that weather change is also leading to spread of dangerous diarrheal illness.   .      for this research follows previous work from the team, which found that.

articles.title: Mayor Woodby provides weekly update of Carter County recovery from Hurricane Helene
articles.summary: The upcoming efforts to remove flood-related debris from Carter County's rivers and lakes highlights the latest weekly update by Mayor Patty Woodby's efforts at recovery from Hurricane Helene. The effort to remove the debris is highlighted in the weekly update from Mayor Woodby.

articles.title: Victoria's Goldfields fast-tracked in bid for World Heritage status
articles.author: Mike Foley
articles.summary: Victoria's non-Indigenous population soared from 29,000 in 1851 to more than 120,000 within three years. Americans, Germans, Scandinavians, Britons and Chinese came to Australia to hunt for gold. Melbourne became one of the world's richest cities. John Brumby has been campaigning for World Heritage listing since 1988.

articles.title: Scientists look to keep NWT's huge carbon stores out of the air
articles.author: Ollie Williams
articles.summary: Next week, scientists will gather in Yellowknife's Chateau Nova Hotel for a Landscape Carbon Workshop to discuss climate change issues in the Northwest Territories. The region has a lot of carbon stored in the boreal forest, peatland and permafrost. The recent wildfires in the NWT emitted more carbon than every country on Earth except for four. Permafrost thaw is another major concern.

articles.title: Milder winter may shift H5N1 seasonal pattern
articles.author: Tom Kiwaradio.Com
articles.summary: The extended fall and unusually mild start of winter delayed the southern migration of many bird species, prolonging last year's H5N1 (avian influenza) season. January ends on a similarly mild note and migratory birds are already beginning their journey north earlier than expected. This shift raises questions about how the virus will behave in the coming months.

articles.title: Norwegian coastal waters are getting warmer
articles.author: Elizaveta Vereykina
articles.summary: According to the Institute of Marine Research, sea water temperature has risen by one or two degrees since 1935. Fisherman Kjell Figenschou reports that the water in the Barents Sea is getting warmer. More fish species typical of southern waters have been discovered along the Norwegian coast over the past 30 years.

articles.title: A TALE OF TWO STORMS
articles.author: Scott Lawson Managing Editor
articles.summary: Every year, the region prepares for Hurricane Season. The summer and fall tend to be the peak of problems. It sometimes starts a little earlier and lasts a little longer, but it's usually longer in the summer and autumn. It usually starts earlier and ends a little later.

articles.title: Ancient Antarctic ice loss offers insights into future climate scenarios (BAS - British Antarctic Survey)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Scientists from the University of Cambridge and British Antarctic Survey have used ice core records to draw new conclusions about how Antarctica was affected by increased global temperatures over 100,000 years. The ice sheet retreated, but not with the added disappearance of the Ronne Ice Shelf.

articles.title: Bayelsa Is Nigeria's Most Climate-Impacted State ' Diri
articles.author: Latestnigeriannews
articles.summary: Governor Douye Diri has described Bayelsa as the most climate-affected state in Nigeria. Governor Diri made this assertion while receiving a delegation from the National Climate Change Secretariat at the Government House in Yenagoa. Dr. Nkiruka Maduekwe is the Director General of the Secretariat.

articles.title: UK Peatlands' Future at Risk from Climate Change
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Peatlands are critical ecosystems for carbon storage and biodiversity. They contain more carbon than all the world's forests despite covering just 3% of the global land surface. The Flow Country, Dartmoor and the Peak District are at risk due to climate change. Western Scotland is projected to retain areas that remain suitable for peatlands.

articles.title: Warmth is weakening the polar vortex. Here's what it means for extreme cold.
articles.author: Scott Dance
articles.summary: The blast of cold that fueled record snowfall across Gulf Coast beaches last week was just the latest to transport frigid air that normally swirls above the North Pole to places much farther south. Rising temperatures in the Arctic are weakening weather systems that normally trap the cold around the poles, making winter weather more chaotic.

articles.title: Meet the quirky Lewis's Woodpecker and its challenges
articles.author: ops@our-hometown.com
articles.summary: Dr. Frank Fogarty will present a talk titled 'Lewis's Woodpecker: Conservation challenges for a unique fire-associated species' on Saturday, February 15 at 5:30 p.m. at the D Street NeighborhoodCenter, 13th and D streets. Tickets are $35 per person until Feb. 8, when the price rises to $50.

articles.title: Scientists make alarming discovery about disease-spreading pests moving to new locations: 'It's definitely a trend'
articles.author: Tina Deines
articles.summary: As the global temperature continues to rise, mosquitoes are expanding their populations and making themselves at home farther north and at higher elevations. This shift is raising concerns about the spread of vector-borne diseases. Backpacker recommends wearing loose-fitting, long-sleeved shirts and pants and wearing clothing and gear treated with permethrin.

articles.title: Industry experts sound the alarm on unsuspecting threat to health insurance: 'If some areas ... become uninhabitable'
articles.author: Leo Collis
articles.summary: Rising temperatures may be reshaping the health insurance market the world over, according to experts from the United States, Canada, Zimbabwe, Hong Kong, and the Middle East. Extreme weather was seen as a problem that was leading to immigration, with people seeking out parts of the world where health risks weren't so high. In the former two countries, citizens might be moving elsewhere to avoid climate risks, either cancelling health insurance policies or seeking plans that suit international coverage. In Canada, mass migration to the global north because of warmer conditions will put strain on health systems and insurance providers.

articles.title: Dutch enjoy early spring but rising sea level looms: KNMI report
articles.author: Hanneke Sanou
articles.summary: Temperatures in the Netherlands have risen by twice as much as in the rest of the world, according to the weather bureau KNMI. Last year marked the hottest year worldwide with a rise in average temperature of over 1.5° compared with the pre-industrial era. In 2024 the figure for the Netherlands was closer to 3°. The Netherlands is warming by 0.4° every 10 years.

articles.title: ‘Another example' of how mass immigration is ‘changing the West': Bolt
articles.summary: Sky News host Andrew Bolt discusses how mass immigration from the third world is 'changing the West' and causing a shift of voters to the right in London today. Mr Bolt is discussing it on Sky News today.   .      in London.

articles.title: Why nature-based climate solutions are growing in popularity in the Wilmington area
articles.author: Gareth McGrath
articles.summary: In North Carolina, 2024 was the second-warmest year on record, with average temperature of 61.5 degrees. All twelve months in 2024 were warmer than the historical average statewide. The weather whiplash has put residents and businesses on notice, with many fearing 2024's weather isn't a one-off event but a sign of things to come as climate change continues to change and modify traditional weather patterns and events. Beach communities are starting to feel the pinch as nourishment projects, the traditional way of dealing with beaches impacted by sea-level rise and storms become increasingly expensive and tough to schedule.

articles.title: Earth's Oceans Have Been On A Record Hot Streak. Here's Why
articles.author: Grist
articles.summary: The rate of ocean warming has more than quadrupled over the past 40 years. Earth's energy imbalance accounts for 44 percent of the extra heat in recent El Niño years. The next 20 years could warm up the oceans more than the last 40. The excess ocean warmth has had wide-ranging consequences.

articles.title: Dinosaurs versus doom-mongers:  Willie Soon: Time Traveller
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: Gorilla Science has been set up by rebels from the world of mainstream media to challenge the flagrant lies and double-speak of governments, the media, the educational establishment and others. They are not funded by Big Oil or Big Coal. They need your financial help.

articles.title: Cold wave disrupts daily life in Janakpur, flights halted
articles.summary: Cold waves in various areas of the Terai region, including Janakpurdham in Madhesh Province, have affected normal life. The poor and the underprivileged are facing many problems due to the cold. The weather is expected to improve in the coming days.

articles.title: Ancient Antarctic Ice Loss Reveals Future Climate Clues
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Scientists from Cambridge and British Antarctic Survey have used ice core records to draw new conclusions about how Antarctica was affected by increased global temperatures over 100,000 years ago. The data suggests that large parts of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet were lost, contributing to significant sea level rise. However, the nearby Ronne Ice Shelf survived.

articles.title: Natural disasters, climate change pose long-term risks to state finances: IIT Bombay
articles.author: Team Asianet Newsable
articles.summary: India experiences five to six tropical cyclones every year. The state government bears much of the disaster response cost after natural disasters such as floods and cyclones. After the disaster, the state has to invest in rebuilding essential infrastructure such as roads, bridges, and homes. These disasters reduce the government's revenues. Public-private partnerships are essential for building a climate-resilient economy.

articles.title: Moderate Weather Expected for Egypt on Thursday, Cairo 22°C
articles.author: Yara Sameh
articles.summary: The Egyptian Meteorological Authority predicts moderate weather to prevail in Cairo, Lower Egypt, North Coast, and North Upper Egypt during Thursday's daylight hours. The Mediterranean Sea will experience low to moderate waves, ranging between 1 meters and 1.5 meters in height. Extremely cold weather is also expected in Egypt in the early hours and at the end of the nighttime.

articles.title: Amami Oshima sea turtle nesting declines to second-lowest level
articles.author: Japan Times
articles.summary: Scientists believe declining populations may be a key factor in the decline of human population. They warn that a long-term analysis is needed to assess the situation and find out what the cause is, and why it's declining.      .

articles.title: Bird numbers rise in Türkiye's Çanakkale due to climate shifts
articles.author: Daily Sabah with DHA
articles.summary: The 2025 Mid-Winter Waterfowl Counts (KOSKS) were conducted in Çanakkale, northwestern Türkiye. The General Directorate of Nature Conservation and National Parks conducted KOSKS in areas important for waterfowl inventories. There was an increase in bird numbers in the last two years due to the heavy snow, cold weather and freezing events in Europe. Cenk Polat highlights the impact of climate change.

articles.title: Russia's Unseasonal Warmth: A Winter Without Snow
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Temperatures in Russia are above freezing. The first 27 days of 2025 could be the hottest on record globally. The unusual weather led to thin ice on Lake Baikal and canceled traditional swim festivities for the Orthodox Epiphany due to safety concerns. Scientists link these conditions to human-caused global warming.

articles.title: Cyclones and Fiscal Strain: Navigating India's Budgetary Storm
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk

articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Populations of birds have been falling for decades. Experts have spent two decades trying to understand what's happening to them at Tiputini. The biodiversity research centre is trying to find out what's wrong with the birds there. It's not clear if humans are to blame.

articles.title: Concern as deteriorating sports fields lead to the spread of plastic, rubber in NSW
articles.summary: There are environmental and health concerns about the spread of rubber and plastic on Sydney's synthetic turf fields that are falling apart and causing problems for the environment and the health.      .   "The problem is with the rubber and the plastic being spread.

articles.title: First Alert Weather: Pendulum swings back to above normal temperatures
articles.author: John Scalzi
articles.summary: La Niña has strengthened in the last few weeks and is forecast to have a greater impact on our weather. High pressure will develop in Alaska and a deep trough of low pressure will form over the West. High-pressure ridge will build over the Southeast and Florida, leading to a warming trend with above-average temperatures. The rest of this week will see temperatures running 2 to 3 degrees above normal. By next week, temperatures could rise significantly.

articles.title: Just Stop Oil Activists Charged After Protest At Sigourney Weaver's West End Play
articles.author: Daniel Welsh
articles.summary: Two Just Stop Oil members have been charged with aggravated trespass after disrupting a performance of The Tempest on Monday night. They will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Tuesday 25 February. The two members of the group claim that the rise in temperature is a 'global shipwreck we can't ignore' and they are calling for action.

articles.title: Why Activism Must Go Beyond Career Ambitions To Drive Real Change
articles.summary: Climate change is one of the biggest threats to our planet. Developed nations have largely weathered the changes due to their infrastructure, but developing countries are bearing the brunt of climate change despite contributing the least to the problem. Pakistan, unfortunately, is among those nations that have contributed minimally to greenhouse gas emissions but are now suffering disproportionately from the climate change. There is a need for dedicated climate activists.

articles.title: An ominous year: the climate change omens for 2025 look very dark indeed
articles.author: The Irish Times
articles.summary: In 2025, global warming continues unabated, from rising surface temperatures to unprecedented melting of land, according to the UNFCCC report. It's a scary time for anyone concerned about climate change.   .   in 2024, there will be record after record broken in 2024.

articles.title: South-West France Residents Concerned About Climate Change: New Study Insights
articles.author: Zane Lilley
articles.summary: People in Nouvelle-Aquitaine ranked above average for safety, trust in the education system and attachment to their region. However, they did not rank 'top' for any aspect of life overall. This is in contrast to Brittany, which overall scored higher.

articles.title: What temperature should a UK house be? GP issues warning
articles.author: Rebecca Carey
articles.summary: There's an optimum temperature for your house according to the NHS's recommended room temperature. Dr Neel Patel has warned Brits not to turn up the central heating above 18°C as it can cause allergies, asthma, migraines, sinus infections and nosebleeds.

articles.title: Gone Too Soon? Delhi's Peak Winter Retreats With No Cold Waves This January
articles.author: Apoorva Misra
articles.summary: January's lowest temperature in Delhi was 4.8°C, well above the sub-2°C lows seen in recent years. Night temperatures hovered over 6°C for most of the month, with 15°C to 25°C during the day. Last year, the national capital experienced five cold wave days when the minimum temperature dipped to 3.3°C.

articles.title: Australia's Housing Crisis: A Nation at Odds
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Gallup survey found that last year's dissatisfaction with housing in Australia soared to record levels. Australia ranked second only to Turkey in housing dissatisfaction within the OECD. The issue is expected to be a focal point in the general election slated for May. The centre-left Labor government has enacted reforms to mitigate the pressures, aiming to construct 1.2 million new homes by 2030.

articles.title: In the most untouched, pristine parts of the Amazon, birds are dying. Scientists may finally know why
articles.author: Tess McClure
articles.summary: Biodiversity research centre in the Ecuadorian Amazon is observing rainforest wildlife in a world untouched by human industry. John G Blake has been there since 2000 to count the birds. The yearly fluctuations he had spent a decade recording slowly stopped their upward leaps. By 2022, their numbers had almost halved and some species had disappeared.

articles.title: In the most untouched, pristine parts of the Amazon, birds are dying. Scientists may finally know why
articles.author: Tess McClure
articles.summary: Biodiversity research centre in the Ecuadorian Amazon is observing rainforest wildlife in a world untouched by human industry. John G Blake has been there since 2000 to count the birds. The yearly fluctuations he had spent a decade recording slowly stopped their upward leaps. By 2022, their numbers had almost halved.

articles.title: An ominous year: the climate change omens for 2025 look very dark indeed
articles.author: Cormac O'Raifeartaigh
articles.summary: In 2024, global warming continues unabated and carbon emissions linked to fossil fuels rose to an all-time record of 37.4 billion tonnes. In June 2024, elections to the European Parliament saw many Green Party politicians lose their seats. In November the Green Party was decimated in the Irish election. In the US, Donald Trump was re-elected to the White House and he is opposed to any action to combat climate change.

articles.title: Extreme heat at World Cup 2026
articles.summary: Next year's FIFA Men's World Cup takes place in the US, Mexico and Canada. New research has warned that nearly 90% of the stadiums could face potentially dangerous levels of heat. Dr Donal Mullan, a climate scientist explains what this means.

articles.title: Patrick Gorman MP on ABC Perth Drive With Adshead
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Dean Smith and Patrick Gorman are in the ABC Drive studio. They are doorknocking in the heat. Inflation is down to 2.4%, but it still sits outside the 2 to 3% band that the RBA is looking for. The government is not celebrating this.

articles.title: Otago Researchers Unlock the Mysteries of Antarctic Fast Ice
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Scientists at the University of Otago have studied the behavior and characteristics of landfast sea ice in Antarctica's McMurdo Sound. The study was published in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans. It shed light on the factors that influence the thickness of fast ice and provides crucial data that can help mitigate future impacts of climate change.

articles.title: Climate Change Poses a Significant Risk to the Future of UK Peatlands
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The future of the UK's peatlands is at a crossroads due to the significant ramifications of climate change. These vital ecosystems serve as key carbon sinks and biodiversity hotspots. Peatlands cover 3% of the global land surface but contain more carbon than all the world's forests combined. Western Scotland may retain suitable areas for peatland ecosystems in the future.

articles.title: Rise in wild goats ‘not unusual'
articles.author: John Conroy
articles.summary: In the year to July 2024, the population of unmanaged rangeland goats in the region rose 17 per cent to 5.89 million. The region takes in everything west of a border and runs from near Tooleybuc on the Murray River, north-east to the Queensland border.

articles.title: Ocean warming rate accelerates by four times than last four decades, says study
articles.author: Kalingatv Bureau
articles.summary: Oceans are warming by 0.27 degrees Celsius per decade between 2019 and 2023. The oceans have broken their record heat 450 times consecutively by record sea surface temperatures. If the level of greenhouse emission is not cut down, the next 20 years would be able to surpass the warmth of the past 40 years.

articles.title: Study examines the long-term financial impact of natural disasters on Indian states
articles.author: Dipti Singh
articles.summary: India's geographical location and monsoon climate make it highly vulnerable to natural disasters such as floods and cyclones. On average, the country experiences five to six tropical cyclones annually. These disasters impose a significant financial strain on state governments. Less disaster-prone states like Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh can manage relief efforts with their own resources and sustain minimal financial losses. Coastal states such as Odisha, Andhra Pradesh and West Bengal face higher recovery costs and greater revenue losses. Public-private partnerships (PPPs) can help build a more climate-resilient economy.

articles.title: Kenya: Weatherman Warns of Increased Fire Risk in Northeastern Region Due to Below-Average Rainfall
articles.author: Susan Simolo
articles.summary: Kenya Meteorological Department warns of an increased risk of fires in the Northeastern region due to expected below-average rainfall during the March-April-May season. Northeastern counties, including Mandera, Marsabit, Wajir, Garissa, and Isiolo, are expected to receive occasional rainfall, but amounts are likely to be below the long-term average for the season.

articles.title: Sharp rise needed in emissions target to help avoid 'crises', advocates say
articles.author: Eloise Gibson
articles.summary: The government is expected to reveal its next climate change target on Thursday night. Countries have until February to reveal their targets for reducing planet heating emissions from 2031 to 2035. Under the Paris Agreement, each target has to be bigger than the last one from that country. The current target is shrinking greenhouse gases by 50 percent from 2005 levels during the decade from 2021 to 2030.

articles.title: Nigeria, Australia Begin Talks to Strengthen Economic Ties
articles.author: Joshua Odeyemi
articles.summary: Nigeria and Australia have commenced high-level bilateral consultations aimed at strengthening economic ties and exploring new areas of cooperation. The talks aim to map out practical measures to strengthen cooperation in areas like trade, investment, and climate change. Marc Innes-Brown, First Assistant Secretary, Middle East and Africa Division, Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, said Nigeria is a crucial partner for Australia internationally and in the region.

articles.title: Russia comes in from the cold, with flowers blooming around Moscow in January
articles.author: Dasha Litvinova
articles.summary: Temperatures in eight Russian regions broke decades-old records on Monday. January in Russia is usually one of the coldest months of the year, but this year it's been unusually warm. The first 27 days of 2025 globally are the hottest on record, dating back to 1940.

articles.title: Is the climate doomsday cult finally losing power?
articles.author: Vijay Jayaraj
articles.summary: Al Gore and John Kerry's climate change predictions have failed to materialize. The credibility gap has widened with extreme actions by groups like Extinction Rebellion and Just Stop Oil. In recent elections in the U.S., Argentina, India, and Italy, voters have increasingly prioritized economic concerns, national security, and tangible environmental issues like local pollution over climate goals.

articles.title: How to survive an inauguration and a winter
articles.author: Bruce Fellman
articles.summary: Bruce Fellman is sitting atop a snow-covered Japanese Holly. A White-throated Sparrow is warm in its down jacket on the other side of the Japanese Holly, which has waxy leaves that laugh at the cold. Bruce Fellman's book "The Snowman" is out now.

articles.title: Climate warnings spur innovation for Trinidad and Tobago's green economy
articles.author: Andrew Gioannetti
articles.summary: Anthony Vieira warned of an environmental triple-whammy: climate change, land degradation and biodiversity loss. Vieira is vice president of the ParlAmericas Network on Climate Change. He warned Port of Spain and other coastal areas could face catastrophic flooding within the next 25 years. He also called for a shift towards regenerative agriculture and sustainable fishing.

articles.title: Aurora and Astronomy: When Space Weather Meets Earth's Atmosphere
articles.author: Mousumi Khatun
articles.summary: The aurora borealis and aurora australis are the Northern Lights in the north (Aurora Borealis) and the Southern Lights in south. They appear as vivid light patterns in the sky, often resembling vibrant curtains or beams. These lights captivate observers.

articles.title: Nigeria, Australia begin talks to strengthen economic ties
articles.author: Daily Trust
articles.summary: Nigeria and Australia have commenced high-level bilateral consultations aimed at strengthening economic ties and exploring new areas of cooperation. The bilateral talks aim to map out practical measures to strengthen cooperation in areas like trade, investment, and climate change. The Director of Regions, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said the talks will focus on trade, mining, agriculture and food security.

articles.title: UK Peatlands Face Climate Change Threat
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Peatlands are critical ecosystems for carbon storage and biodiversity, containing more carbon than all the world's forests. New research shows that vast areas of the UK's peatlands are likely to be unsuitable for peat accumulation by 2061-80 due to climate change. Flow Country, Dartmoor and the Peak District are particularly at risk. Western Scotland is projected to retain peatland, underscoring its importance in future conservation efforts.

articles.title: Students sensitised to significance of Erramatti Dibbalu in Vizag
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: The 12,000-year-old red sand dunes were once spread over 850 acres but have been reduced to 400 acres due to sea erosion and human interference, say experts. The dunes are no longer visible from the sea. The sand dune area is shrinking due to human interference.

articles.title: Climate action: Can the world move on without US under Trump?
articles.author: Paul Omorogbe
articles.summary: On January 20, Donald Trump signed an executive order withdrawing the US from the Paris Agreement. The Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty on climate change. It was adopted by 196 Parties at the UN Climate Change Conference (COP21) in Paris, France, on December 12, 2015. It entered into force on November 4, 2016. It does not require countries to cut their emissions but works through international peer pressure and countries' domestic laws.

articles.title: Wintery mix of weather conditions expected to impact qathet
articles.author: Tanya Hill
articles.summary: Weather alert issued for Thursday afternoon and following few days on northern Sunshine Coast. Environment and Climate Change Canada has issued a special weather statement warning of impending wintery conditions in the qathet region from Saltery Bay to Powell River. A low pressure system is making its way towards the BC coast with steady precipitation beginning Thursday afternoon.

articles.title: Wintery mix of weather conditions expected to impact qathet
articles.author: Tanya Hill
articles.summary: Weather alert issued for Thursday afternoon and following few days on northern Sunshine Coast. Environment and Climate Change Canada has issued a special weather statement warning of impending wintery conditions in the qathet region from Saltery Bay to Powell River. A low pressure system is making its way towards the BC coast with steady precipitation beginning Thursday afternoon.

articles.title: Mangrove plantation earned Sindh $50m in carbon credits, moot told
articles.author: Fatima S Attarwala
articles.summary: The Sindh Chief Minister Syed Murad Ali Shah is at the 3rd Pakistan Climate Conference by the Overseas Investors Chamber of Commerce & Industry (OICCI). Sindh's average annual temperature has increased by 0.5°C since the 1960s. Failure to act decisively could lead to a further rise of 1.3°C to 1.5 °C by 2050. Sindh has implemented coastal protection measures and mangrove restoration projects. Two billion mangroves have already been planted in various areas of Sindh as part of the Delta Blue Carbon project. The project has earned Sindh government about $50 million through carbon credits.

articles.title: Is Climate Change Speeding Up? Study Finds Ocean Warming Four Times Faster Than In 1980s
articles.summary: Oceans are warming at 0.27 degrees Celsius per decade during 2019-23, compared to 0.06 degrees Celsius every decade in the late 1980s. Global ocean temperatures hit record highs for 450 days straight in 2023 and early 2024. El Nino, a natural warming event in the Pacific, contributed to the record-breaking heat.

articles.title: Sindh govt earns $14.747m through carbon credit sales, says CM Murad
articles.summary: The Sindh government has restored 160,000 hectares of mangroves in the Indus Delta and sold 2.88 MTCO2e carbon credits for $14.747 million. The Sindh Chief Minister Syed Murad Ali Shah was speaking at the 3rd Pakistan Climate Conference hosted by the Overseas Investors Chamber of Commerce & Industry (OICCI). Pakistan is 5th most climate-vulnerable nation.

articles.title: Climate change poses 'security threat' to Irish economy and society
articles.author: Cormac O’Keeffe
articles.summary: Storm surges, flooding, and coastal erosion are likely to pose'significant risks' to the security of Irish society and economy in the coming years, according to the Defence Forces Review 2024. Climate change threatens Ireland's marine infrastructure, shipping, and offshore energy installations. Far right uses climate change for its own ends, such as the claim that 'Ireland is full, and that climate migration poses a threat to national identity.

articles.title: Cormac O'Keefe: Climate change and State inaction create a 'perfect storm'
articles.author: Cormac O’Keeffe
articles.summary: Lieutenant Wietse Buwalda wrote in the Defence Forces' Review 2024 that Ireland's maritime security is vulnerable due to lack of investment in the Naval Service and limited capabilities of agencies charged with its protection. The report is being launched today by Chief of Staff Seán Clancy at UCC.

articles.title: Geraldton keeps sweltering through 40C plus days, with no relief in sight, according to Bureau of Meteorology
articles.summary: Geraldton is sweltering through 40C plus days, with no relief in sight, according to the Bureau of Meteorology. It's been 40C for the last two days. It will be 40C or more for the next few days.

articles.title: CNMI environmental champions criticise Trump's Paris withdrawal
articles.author: Mark  Rabago
articles.summary: Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement has upset environmental champions in the CNMI. Sheila Babauta, a former CNMI lawmaker, said the withdrawal from the accord can result in fast-tracking processes and bypassing regulations meant to protect the environment. Angelo Villagomez, senior fellow at the Center for American Progress in Washington, said it's disappointing that Trump is weakening the position of the United States in the world and ceding leadership on climate to geopolitical rivals.

articles.title: Climate fight: Trump leaves, Pakistan leads
articles.author: Soha Nisar
articles.summary: Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Paris Climate Agreement sends shockwaves through international climate efforts. For Pakistan, the Paris Agreement was more than a global pact: it was a lifeline. Pakistan contributes less than 1% of global greenhouse gas emissions, but it bears a disproportionate share of climate impacts. Pakistan's rural areas and growing urban centres represent vast opportunities to pioneer sustainable solutions. Investments in energy efficiency, smart grids and green infrastructure can transform Pakistan into a leader in climate resilience.

articles.title: Should I give up on climate change? – DW – 01/30/2025
articles.author: Gabriel Borrud
articles.summary: The US has pulled out of the Paris Agreement and its president is chanting "Drill, baby, drill!" It's fair to ask if your own personal climate footprint even matters anymore, as the US president thinks it doesn't.   .

articles.title: Antarctic ice sheet may be less vulnerable to collapse than expected
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: The West Antarctic ice sheet could cause metres of sea level rise if it collapses. It may have survived an even warmer period than it is experiencing now, more than 120,000 years ago, and it could have caused a lot of damage then too. It could cause a lot more damage now.

articles.title: Farmers grow fewer varieties due to high costs, climate change
articles.author: Hürriyet Daily News
articles.summary: Increasing costs and climate-induced are the main reasons for the increase in costs and the rise of climate change. It's not just a matter of getting more expensive, it's also about the environment too. It is also about people's health.

articles.title: Climate Change Amplified Likelihood of L.A. Wildfires
articles.author: The Arabian Post
articles.summary: The likelihood of wildfires in Los Angeles has increased by 35 percent due to climate change. Rising temperatures, altered precipitation patterns and prolonged droughts have contributed to the current severity of the wildfires in the area.      . .

articles.title: ‘Everyone has an impact': how to start reducing your environmental footprint
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: As fires tear through California and Trump sets back efforts to curb the rise of global temperatures, what can individuals do to make a difference? "Misery to millions of people" is what Trump's words say to many people. "What can you do to help them?" is what I ask.

articles.title: 2025 To Be A Pivotal Year For U.S. Corporate Action On Deforestation
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: The stage is set for 2025 to be a crucial year for deforestation action. What happens in that year will have implications for the private sector and the global economy. It will be crucial for the environment and for the economy in the long-term. It is important to take action now.

articles.title: Nat Fortune: Bad climate arguments
articles.author: The Recorder
articles.summary: Letters to the editor regularly declare that nothing needs to be done about the climate change. The climate is changing and it always has been changing, according to the scientists. The current climate is getting worse, according the scientists, and nothing needs be done to prevent it.

articles.title: What the Budget can prioritise for climate action in agriculture
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: In 2024, we breached the 1.5-degree Celsius warming limit for the first time. About 8 per cent of the world's farmland is expected to become unsuitable for agriculture due to climate change. Agrarian economies are likely to be hit the hardest.

articles.title: Hurricane Helene's $5 billion toll strains NCDOT resources
articles.author: Business Journal
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene's $5 billion price tag forces North Carolina to navigate uncharted waters in infrastructure recovery. North Carolina is trying to recover from Hurricane Helene at a cost of $5.5 billion. The recovery is expected to take place over the next few years.

articles.title: The coming update to The New Hampshire Coastal Flood Risk Summary
articles.author: Seacoast Online
articles.summary: The New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services (NHDES) has announced the required update to the state of the science relevant to coastal flood risks in New Hampshire. The document provides updated projections of sea level rise, coastal storms, groundwater rise, precipitation, and freshwater flooding for coastal New Hampshire as a result of the January 2024 storms.

articles.title: Pakistan Faces Highest Climate Risk in South Asia: UNICEF Report
articles.author: Khaama Press
articles.summary: UNICEF report has ranked Pakistan among the countries where children face the highest risks from climate change-related disasters. Pakistan is the most vulnerable nation in South Asia in this regard. The report highlights the severe threats posed to millions of children in Pakistan due to escalating climate change.

articles.title: Future of UK peatlands under threat due to climate change
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The UK's peatlands face an uncertain future amid the escalating impacts of climate change due to rising global temperatures.    i.e. the loss of the peaty areas will have a negative impact on the environment. i.yours sincerely.

articles.title: Agri residue, waste burning main sources of air pollution in South Asia, says European agency CAMS
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: Agriculture residue burning, waste burning, and industrial and transport emissions were among the main sources of air pollution in many areas of South Asia and South-East Asia in January. Fine particulate matter PM2.5 was the main cause of pollution in the region.

articles.title: Tiwai Peninsula Vegetation Fire Update
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: The fire has grown to 1,200 hectares across the centre of the peninsula with an 18 km perimeter. It's due to higher temperatures and wind speed this afternoon, and it's spread due to the higher temperatures. It has been burning since yesterday afternoon.

articles.title: Infrastructure Shows Effects of Climate Change
articles.author: TT News
articles.summary: Warming temperatures are hammering roads that were built for a different climate, ballooning repair budgets and cutting off communities from goods and services due to climate change.    i.e. roads built for the different climate are being damaged by the warming temperatures.

articles.title: 'Less snow': Warm January weather breaks records in Moscow
articles.author: Khaleejtimes
articles.summary: January 2025 is on track to be one of the warmest in Moscow on record, meteorologists reported on Wednesday. Two of the past days broke all-time daily temperature highs. Thermometer readings on Wednesday have not dipped below an "April-like" 3.8 degrees Celsius.

articles.title: Big trees crucial to migrate B.C. forests under climate change, finds study
articles.author: North Shore News
articles.summary: In the coming decades, British Columbia is expected to face more drought and scorching temperatures. The changes in climate are expected to drive an exodus of wildlife seeking refuge up mountains and further north. This is bad for trees, which often rely on rain for survival.

articles.title: Lot Lines: Resilience in the built environment
articles.author: The Journal Record
articles.summary: Extreme weather events and human-made crises are becoming more frequent. There is a need for resilience in the built environment, says Dr. Michael Schumacher.    for more information, visit www.scep.org/resilient-built-environment.

articles.title: Annapolis, Anne Arundel County climate lawsuits against oil companies dismissed
articles.author: Maryland Daily Record
articles.summary: Anne Arundel County Circuit judge dismisses a pair of lawsuits against fossil fuel companies. The suits alleged they are responsible for causing and accelerating climate change in Annapolis and Anne Arunderl County. The lawsuits were brought by the City of Annapolis.

articles.title: Letter to the Editor: We are in a new era
articles.author: Lewiston Sun Journal
articles.summary: Scientists announced that 2024 will be the hottest year. Los Angeles burned for days on end because of the firestorm and scientists say it will be hotter in 2024.      .   for confidential support call 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: Earth's warming is weakening the polar vortex. Here's what that means for extreme cold.
articles.author: Scott Dance
articles.summary: There is no evidence that extreme cold is becoming more frequent or intense, but rising temperatures in the Arctic are weakening weather systems that normally trap the cold around the poles. This shift is encouraging the erratic weather patterns high in the atmosphere that can cast chills even on regions with typically balmy climates. The past two years were significantly hotter than any other period in human history.

articles.title: How to green Karachi
articles.author: Syed Asad Ali Shah
articles.summary: Karachi is one of the least green megacities in the world with less than 0.5% tree canopy coverage. Pakistan's overall forest coverage is just 4.8% and Sindh's is 2.5%. Karachi has a poor air quality and poor drainage infrastructure. Sindh needs to take leadership of a project to develop a plantation and solar energy generation.

articles.title: What To Expect From NZ's New Climate Goals
articles.summary: New Zealand's national contribution to reducing greenhouse gas emissions is due to be announced today. This is a responsibility under the Paris Agreement, from which the US has recently withdrawn. Dr Rebecca Peer, Senior Lecturer, Civil and Natural Resources Engineering Department, University of Canterbury, is looking out for the budget number and the corresponding percent reduction from the typical 2005 baseline. Dr James Renwick, Professor of Physical Geography, Victoria University of Wellington, believes the commitments under the agreement still matter.

articles.title: Fowl formation
articles.summary: Geese fly through the sky above Clarkston on Thursday. August Frank/Lewiston Tribune August Frank.   August Frank, August Frank and August Frank are journalists from Lewiston, Maine.  October 1st, 2013.  July 1st. 2013.

articles.title: Seal frolics in calm waters at marina
articles.summary: The Australian fur seal is the largest fur seal, often growing to more than two metres in length. It has large brown eyes, a thick coat, and long whiskers. It also has a large brown eye, thick coat and brown hair. It's the most common species of seal in Australia.
